Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Fundamental Studies on Ultrasonic Vibration Assisted Laser Surface Modification (UV-LSM) of Materials

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) grant provides funding for the development of novel ultrasonic vibration-assisted laser processes for the surface modifications of advanced materials, including light alloys, metal matrix composites (MMCs), and porous ceramics. The proposed processing approach is expected to achieve refined grain structure in light alloys, deeper penetration of ceramic reinforcement in metal matrix composites, and denser crack-free surfaces in porous ceramics. The research project will investigate the effect of combined laser operation and ultrasonic vibrations on the development of microstructure and properties of these materials. The microstructural features such as grain size (light alloys), depth of particle penetration (MMCs), and depth of infiltration (porous ceramics) will be characterized using combination of experimental and computational approaches. The effect of these microstructural features on hardness, strength, corrosion/wear resistance, and residual stress state of the modified surfaces will be systematically investigated. Major emphasis of the proposed activities will be on establishing processing-microstructure-properties relationships for these advanced materials.

If successful, the proposed project will significantly advance the state-of-the-art in laser surface engineering for improving surface properties of materials. The development of these new ultrasonic vibration assisted laser surface modification processes will accelerate the utilization of surface modified light alloys, MMCs, and porous ceramics in wider applications requiring improved performance. In addition, the proposed project will provide unique hands-on-experience opportunities to the diverse groups of undergraduate and graduate students to prepare them for future career in this important field of manufacturing research. The results of this research project will be widely disseminated to the academic, research, and manufacturing community through journal publications, conference presentations, and proceedings.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Research Project Overview  

The long term goal of this Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) project was to develop novel ultrasonic vibration-assisted laser surface engineering approaches for the processing of materials. The approaches involved simultaneous application of high frequency ultrasonic vibrations to the metallic substrates during laser surface melting. The simultaneous application of ultrasonic vibrations to the metallic substrates modifies the flow in the laser melted material, resulting in several desirable effects such as grain refinement and expulsion of molten material with applications in surface engineering and machining. The major objective of the project was to investigate the effect of laser processing and ultrasonic vibration parameters on the microstructure and properties development. Both experimental and thermal analysis approaches were used to establish to effect of ultrasonic vibrations during laser surface processing on the development of grain structure, surface features/patterns, and micro-holes.

 

Important Outcomes – Intellectual Merit

The project demonstrated that the application of ultrasonic vibrations to the metallic substrates during laser surface melting modifies the microstructure and surface features of the modified surfaces. The experimental results showed that the ultrasonic vibration and laser processing parameters could be effectively designed to control the nature of interactions/modifications at the surface. The results showed that the ultrasonic vibration-induced agitation and cavitation in the melt pool cause fragmentation of grains, resulting in refined microstructure in the resolidified surfaces. When the severe vibrations characterized by higher displacements of vibrations are applied, the vibrations facilitate the expulsion of molten material from the substrate. Such expulsion of molten material generates surface features such as craters and deep micro-holes at the surface with applications in surface patterning and machining, respectively. The project established the effect of both ultrasonic vibrations and laser processing parameters on the development of microstructure and surface properties, thus significantly advancing the current state-of-the-art in the area.

 

Important Outcomes – Broader Impacts

The project established the effects such as grain refinement and melt expulsion due to simultaneous application of ultrasonic vibrations during laser melting. These effects are likely to be useful in a range of processes such as surface modification, surface patterning, surface micro-machining, and atomization of materials to improve surface quality and/or process efficiency. The project enabled the principal investigator to establish a research program in the areas of laser processing and also shaped his future research direction in this area. The project also provided training opportunities to several graduate and undergraduate students. These students were trained on laser processing and advanced characterization of materials, including microstructure, wear, and corrosion testing. These training opportunities will prepare the students for future career in the important area of advanced manufacturing. The principal investigator also provided hands-on training opportunities to several high school students on hardness and wear testing of materials through participation in OSU National Lab Day. For potential broader impacts, the results of this project are widely disseminated through publications in journal articles, presentations in international conferences, and graduate courses in manufacturing area.
